content: Founders raising VC make the same two competition mistakes that instantly kill investor interest.1. Say you have no competition? You just told investors you haven't talked to a single customer.2. List competitors without context? You just missed your chance to show billion-dollar potential.After raising my pre-seed, here‚Äôs what I know really works üëáüèæMISTAKE # 1: Saying "we don't have any competition"If you‚Äôre solving a problem worth solving, then you have competition. It‚Äôs either other companies or it‚Äôs how your potential customers are currently solving the problem.At Chezie, we started our fundraise claiming that we didn‚Äôt have competition in the community management space, because, technically, we didn‚Äôt; none of the companies we pitched already had a solution in place.BUT, our customers were already using Slack, Google Sheets, and email to manage their groups.After ~20 pitches, we realized that these systems were our real competition.If you tell an investor that you don‚Äôt have competition, they‚Äôre going to think that you‚Äôre either naive or that you haven‚Äôt done customer discovery.MISTAKE # 2: Naming competitors without the investment landscapeI recently worked with a fintech founder building in the private asset space. When I asked about his competition, he initially said this:"Our competition is Carta and AngelList."Cool. So what?You need to go deeper. Specifically, you need to discuss the investment landscape in your industry.Here‚Äôs what we changed his approach to:‚ÄúCarta and AngelList have both grown to billion-dollar companies, but they don't touch [specific asset class]. That's our billion-dollar opportunity.‚ÄùNow investors hear:1. This market already produces unicorns2. There's a specific gap worth billionsThat's how you turn competition into opportunity.THE FIX: Make your competition slide pitch FOR youDon‚Äôt treat competition like a checkbox. Use it to show market validation and your specific angle- The intensity of the problem (how frustrated customers are with the existing solutions)- Market validation (billion-dollar outcomes exist)- Your specific angle (what giants are missing)Your competition slide should make investors think "this founder sees an opportunity everyone else missed,‚Äù not "this space is crowded" or "this founder is clueless."The difference between a polite pass and a partner meeting can come down to how you frame the competition.What competition mistake have you seen kill a pitch? content: Funding will not save your company.It's tempting for founders to believe that $1M pre-seed will solve their startup's challenges.The truth is that raising capital only magnifies existing problems.Here's exactly how I've seen funding destroy startups instead of saving them:1. Broken product developmentYou believe: "Funding means we can hire engineers and accelerate our roadmap!"What happens: You don‚Äôt talk to customers (which you can do without funding), so you create features for misaligned customers who eventually leave. You end up with a product entirely built on what you THOUGHT customers wanted instead of what they would actually pay for.2. Wasteful marketing spendYou believe: "After we raise, we'll invest in advertising and rapidly grow our user base!"What happens: You burn through cash on paid acquisition, reaching irrelevant audiences because you never invested time in defining your target customer.3. Slow and inconsistent salesYou believe: "Funding lets us build a sales team and scale our sales organization!"What happens: You hire sales reps prematurely without mastering founder-led sales. Without a proven playbook, there's no repeatability, and those hires fail. Plus, you increased your burn with these hires, so now that 24 months of runway you had has shrunk to just 6 months.Here's what I've discovered through building Chezie:Venture capital must be treated as fuel for an existing flame, not the spark itself.- Found product-market fit and ready to scale? Raise money to build faster.- Figured out a way to get in front of customers? Raise money so you can do it more frequently and quickly.- Consistently closing deals and surpassed $1M in ARR? Raise money to hire an SDR who now has a playbook to follow.If you‚Äôre still navigating product development, go-to-market, or sales fundamentals (which is entirely normal, by the way), don‚Äôt raise money.Instead, invest the time to solve these first.Abandon the fantasy that venture capital will rescue you. Embrace constraints, put in the work, and then leverage capital as an accelerant.I'm adding one more example of how founders assume funding will save them in the comments!What's the biggest mistake you made (or saw someone make) after raising their first round? Drop it in the comments - your story might save another founder from making the same error.

We generated our first 100+ qualified leads from a single webinar with zero ad spend.If I were a first-time founder looking to build pipeline fast, here's exactly how I'd do it.Webinars are the most underutilized content tool for founders. We host 1-2 events a month, and they drive millions in pipeline for us.BEFORE THE WEBINAR1. Find a burning topic by searching LinkedIn for questions in your niche. Look for posts with high engagement but outdated answers.2. Identify the perfect host - someone who either works at a notable company OR has a strong following in your space. 3. Create a title that promises transformation, not information. "From Intent to Impact: How to Get the Most Out of Your ERGs" beats "ERG Best Practices" every time.4. Set up a form for people to register. Keep it short, but include these questions- Name- Email- Company name- Job title/department- Their #1 burning question about [topic]5. Use the questions from the registrations to compile a list of questions for your host. These will be 75% of your fireside chat.6. Create marketing materials for the event.7. Use the marketing materials from step 6 to publicize the webinar on your personal LinkedIn and to your company‚Äôs email list.8. Send the marketing materials from step 6 to your host. Encourage them to promote to their networks (they have influence and will attract potential customers)9. Send reminder emails to people who registered 1 week, 1 day, and 1 hour before the event.10. Test your tech setup 24 hours before. Nothing kills momentum like technical difficulties.AFTER THE WEBINAR (where the magic happens)11. Here‚Äôs how to think about it as a founder.When building Chezie, we looked at two different types of competitors:1. Other companies2. In 99% of our early sales calls, we had to explain why Chezie was a better solution than the status quo, not why we were better than other platforms.We sold them on the amount of time they lost using those systems, and more importantly, the opportunity cost of *not* using a dedicated solution for their groups: Missing data about impact, a poor member experience, and an inability to expand the program and secure more budget.Unless there‚Äôs already a huge player in your space (for example, if you‚Äôre creating a better version of Slack), the status quo is what you should focus 90% of your time on. content: The best fundraising advice I ever received came from a founder who's raised $353M:Raise on traction or vision, but never both.In a brief interaction with Christina Cacioppo of Vanta, she shared this nugget with me. VCs want to invest in businesses that can be MASSIVE. Your job as a founder is to prove that you're building something that can reach that scale.If you're early-stage, you might be able to prove it with your traction, but it's unlikely.For Chezie, raising on traction was leading with something like this:"We've grown to $100k ARR in 6 months with 5 enterprise customers."We thought that this traction would be more than enough for VCs to invest, but there was one problem:We couldn't tell how this grows to $100M in ARR.Sure, $100k is impressive.But VCs don't invest for $100k. Or $1M. Or even $10M.Every VC must believe that what you're building can grow to $100M ARR.If they don't believe that, there's nothing you can say to get their buy-in. It doesn't matter how much traction you have, how great your product is, or how impressive your team is.It's $100M or pass.So, after 25-ish meetings, we pivoted to raising on vision:"We want to help enterprises connect their most under-utilized asset (employee resource groups) to their business goals, like building a product or generating sales.‚ÄùBoom.That's a vision-first story that a venture capitalist can get excited about.And it worked. When we switched from pitching traction to pitching vision, our meetings changed completely. Investors leaned in, and the right questions were asked. And finally, the checks ($800k worth) started coming in.Traction sells the present, but vision sells the future. And VCs are in the business of betting on futures.So, if you're a first-time founder struggling to raise money, ask yourself this: Am I trying to sell both traction and vision? Choose one lane (probably your vision) and go all in. Your bank account will thank you.What‚Äôs the best fundraising advice you ever got? Share in the comments üëáüèæ

content: We were 90 days from running out of money before it finally hit me:My ego was stopping me from doing what was best for the company. Founder ego kills more startups than anything else. Here‚Äôs why and how founders can work around it.Great founders walk the line between confident and arrogant. You don‚Äôt start a company without much self-belief.But that confidence can easily lead to ego-driven decisions. A few examples:1. Instead of directly asking a customer to pay for what you‚Äôre building, you jump straight into building the product because you‚Äôre so confident that you know what the customer needs. Then, when you try to sell it, you realize you‚Äôve wasted time and money building something no one wants. 2. Instead of sending monthly updates and keeping your investors in the loop, you hide bad news and only come to them when it‚Äôs too late to do anything about it.3. Instead of being realistic about needing to shut down the company, you keep pushing because you think you‚Äôre just one breakthrough away from turning things around.I can say all of this because I‚Äôve had to come to terms with these things while building Chezie. However, it‚Äôs important not to let that cloud your decision-making. content: I‚Äôve secured over $1.2M in funding for my company. But the path has not been what you‚Äôd expect.After 3 years of building Chezie, here's our actual fundraising journey:- $20K of our own savings- $275K from grants- $160K from friends/family- $110K from pitch competitions- $100K from accelerators- $470K from VCs- $25K from revenue-based financingTwo things most founders miss:1. Revenue unlocks everything Without paying customers, we wouldn't have qualified for grants, VC, or loans.  Focus on revenue first and all of the other funding options become available to you.  2. Don't limit your options Only about a third of our funding came from VCs. Another third was completely equity-free.  Be open to whatever funding source you can get to reach your goals. The reality is that there's no 'right way' to fund your startup.Whether working your day job longer, consulting to get some early revenue, taking loans, or raising from friends and family, do whatever works. The best funding source is the one that keeps your company alive.And sometimes that means taking the path others won't. content: Pet peeve: when people say fundraising is just like sales. Fundraising is not sales because it runs on FOMO. Here‚Äôs how VC actually works and why founders should prioritizing creating FOMO when raisingüëáüèæI've seen founders with great metrics struggle, and I've seen founders with those same metrics raise millions just because a top VC said yes. In sales, having impressive logos matters. But ultimately, if you can't prove your product solves a customer's problem, they won't buy.VC funding doesn't work like that.VCs know that 90% of their returns will come from 1-2 companies in their portfolio. Missing the next big thing hurts more than backing the wrong thing.So when a respected investor commits, others rush in. Not because the company suddenly got better, but because no one wants to miss out.Yes, fundraising and sales share some DNA:‚Ä¢ You're selling a vision‚Ä¢ You have to sell up the decision-making chain‚Ä¢ You must be able to handle objectionsBut customer decisions are rational: "Will this solve my problem?"VC decisions are emotional: "What if this is the next unicorn and I miss it?"I think it's important that you understand this difference. Sometimes closing your round isn't about a better pitch - it's about creating FOMO.
